author: Shaun Eade
title: Israel Adesanya eyes history with two tournaments in four days
text:
Israel Adesanya eyes history with two tournaments in four days SHAUN EADE Last updated 15:00, October 25 2015 Martin Hunter 
Israel Adesanya, left, beat Lance Bryant last time they fought in the Super 8 in March. 
Israel Adesanya has his eyes on making history by claiming Super 8 and King of the Ring titles within four days of each other. 
But his most experienced opponent, Manawatu's Lance Bryant, has questioned his ability to handle the gruelling schedule. 
Adesanya will fight in the King in the Ring eight-man Eliminator Series on October 31 and will then take part in the Super 8 four-man cruiserweight tournament on November 3. 
The 25-year-old Nigerian, who lives in New Zealand, is the reining Super 8 cruiserweight champion and a two-time King of the Ring cruiserweight winner. 
He will fight in the heavyweight division for Saturday's King of the Ring Tournament. 
"I am trying to make history because I don't think there is anyone else who has won four major tournaments in a year in kickboxing and boxing; I don't think anyone in the world has done it," he said. 
"I stay ready and I fight smart. My style of fighting is that I take calculated risks where I don't take any injuries. 
"I am very confident that I will come out of the King of the Ring unscathed go into the Super 8 easy as." 
If he was to claim both titles, he would have to win five fights - three in the King of the Ring and two in the Super 8. 
Bryant was looking forward to getting back in the ring with the man who beat him in the Super 8 in March. 
The 35-year-old five-time New Zealand amateur champion put that loss down to fatigue. 
But he believed that was an issue that would more likely be bothering his opponent this time. 
"I will be watching him fighting the kickboxing match," he said. 
"No one is Superman are they? If the draw goes right, he will be fighting four fights before he gets into the ring with me." 
"It is just using the top couple of inches. He is an athlete, but when some one brings him down, he'll come back down to earth." 
At 181cm, Bryant is 10cm shorter than Adesanya. 
He said he has focused his training on fighting taller boxers. 
But Adesanya believed his older competitor would struggle to keep up with him. 
"I have already seen Lance, I have felt his movements," he said. 
"He was a solid competitor and I sure he will have improved. But he has got to realise that I have improved ten-fold as well." 
Joining the duo in the tournament is fellow kickboxer Zane Hopman. 
The 25-year-old was a sparring partner of Bryant's before he signed up for the fight. 
He said Bryant was a "stand and bang kind of man". 
He was most looking forward to getting into the ring with Adesanya. 
The fourth fighter is 33-year-old former New Zealand amateur champion Jamie Porter. 
Adesanya did not believe any of the other boxers would cause him any issues. 
"I would not be in the fight if I did not know I was going to win," he said. 
"Christmas is coming up. I need that bonus money for Christmas shopping." - Stuff
